question: Question_08
sols:
To find the radius of convergence, we use the ratio test. Let
$a_n = \frac{\ln(n+2)}{|x-2|^n}.$

\begin{align*}
\left|\frac{a_{n+1}}{a_n}\right| 
&= \frac{|x-2|^{n+1}}{\ln(n+1+2) } \cdot \frac{\ln(n+2)}{|x-2|^n}\\
&= |x-2|\frac{\ln(n+2)}{\ln(n+3)} \to  |x-2| \text{ as } n\to\infty .\end{align*}

To see that $\frac{\ln(n+2)}{\ln(n+3)} \to  1 \text{ as } n\to\infty,$
note that

\begin{align*}
\left|  \frac{\ln(n+2)}{\ln(n+3)} -1 \right| &=\left|  \frac{\ln(n+2)-\ln(n+3)}{\ln(n+3)} \right| =\left|  \frac{\ln\left(\frac{n+2}{n+3}\right)}{\ln(n+3)} \right| \end{align*}

Since logarithm is continuous on its domain, the numerator satisfies

\begin{align*}
\lim_{n\to\infty}\ln\left(\frac{n+2}{n+3}\right)&=\ln\left( \lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{n+2}{n+3}\right)= \ln\left( \lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{1+2/n}{1+3/n}\right) = \ln(1)=0.\end{align*}

In the denominator, $\ln(n+3)\to \infty$ as $n\to\infty$.

We conclude that

$\left|  \frac{\ln(n+2)}{\ln(n+3)} -1 \right| \to 0$; that is,
$\frac{\ln(n+2)}{\ln(n+3)}\to 1,$ as $n\to\infty.$

By the ratio test, it follows that the series is absolutely convergent
if and only if $|x-2|<1.$ Therefore, the radius of convergence is equal
to 1.

In order to determine the interval of convergence, it remains to
determine whether the series is convergent at the endpoints, $x=2\pm 1.$

At $x = 3,$ the series is equal to

\begin{align*}\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{(3-2)^n}{\ln(n+2)} = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\ln(n+2)}.\end{align*}

By comparison with $\sum_{n=1}^\infty\frac{1}{n},$ this series is
divergent. (To compare, note that
$\frac{1}{\ln(n+2)} >\frac{1}{n+2} \geq \frac1{3n}.$)

At $x = 1$ the series is equal to

\begin{align*}\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{(1-2)^n}{\ln(n+2)} = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{(-1)^n}{\ln(n+2)}\end{align*}

By the alternating series test, this converges.

Hence, the interval of convergence is $[1,3)$ .
